What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Felt much more confident with the grammar of Middle Egyptian after taking the course and learned some cool stuff about hieratic.
How to read Ancient Egyptian Texts at an intermediate level as well as a review of grammar
This class gave me a huge improvement in my ability to translate Egyptian. I also learned more about Egyptian history and culture in this class than any previous Egyptian language class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Readings were interesting and the grammar lessons were very informative. I sometimes wished, however, that one of the readings might have been a bit less mainstream; since translations were available and vocab was almost always in Faulkner, we always had a crutch when translating. Our hieratic lesson was very interesting, and I would love to see that become its own course.

Strengths: Grammar Review, Professor Knowledge
Weaknesses: Very Disorganized, Grading Unclear

There was a lot of time spent on review, but this is not really a weakness of this class, but rather, a result of the introductory courses teaching Allen rather than Standard Theory. The best way to improve this class is really to teach ST in L1 and L2. The syllabus was largely changed as the class went on as Professor Darnell got a better idea of the strengths and weaknesses of the class, which made sense, but highly schedule-oriented people may have found that confusing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Middle Egyptian is a super fun language and Professor Darnell is an engaging and clearly animated lecturer.
I would recommend this course only to a student who is very interested in learning Egyptian.

If you're really interested in Ancient Egypt or a language nut, yes. If you're just trying to fulfill your language requirement, there are other languages with more real-world advantages that may keep you more engaged. Learning an ancient language that is very different from English has its own advantages though, and really stretches your mind in a way that, say, French, wouldn't.
